def: {bc} greatest or highest in degree, number, or amount

dt: {bc}greatest or highest in degree, number, or amount

dt.t: This is a matter of the {it}utmost{/it} importance/urgency. [=this is an extremely important/urgent matter]
I have the {it}utmost{/it} [={it}greatest{/it}] respect for the teachers here.
the {it}utmost{/it} limit

shortdef: greatest or highest in degree, number, or amount

def: {bc} the highest point or degree that can be reached

dt: {bc}the highest point or degree that can be reached

dt.t: This new system represents the {it}utmost{/it} in modern technology.
It's designed to provide the {it}utmost{/it} in comfort.
We {phrase}did our utmost{/phrase} to help. [=we did all that we could do to help]
We had to push ourselves {phrase}to the utmost{/phrase} to finish the job in time.

shortdef: the highest point or degree that can be reached

stems: what is someone doing with something?
what do you think you're doing with
what do you think youre doing with
it has something to do with
it's got something to do with
its got something to do with
it has nothing to do with
it's got everything to do with
its got everything to do with
didn't have anything to do with
didnt have anything to do with

def: used with {it}what{/it} to ask or talk about a person's job

dt.t: We should {it}do{/it} something special to celebrate your birthday.
This crime was {it}done{/it} deliberately.
I have to {it}do{/it} some chores this afternoon.
Tell me what to {it}do{/it} and I'll {it}do{/it} it.
I'm obliged to {it}do{/it} my duty.
He {it}does{/it} his work without complaining.
I {it}do{/it} the ironing on Wednesdays and the cooking on Thursdays. [=I iron on Wednesdays and cook on Thursdays]
I {it}did{/it} a favor for him. = I {it}did{/it} him a favor.
{ldquo}What do you {it}do{/it} with this lever? = What does this lever {it}do{/it}?{rdquo} {ldquo}It operates the pump.{rdquo}
He {it}did{/it} a lot for us.
What can I {it}do{/it} to help you? = What can I {phrase}do for{/phrase} you? [=how can/may I help you?]
What have I {phrase}done to{/phrase} you to make you so angry?
Have you {phrase}done something to/with{/phrase} this room? [=have you changed this room in some way?] It looks different.
My knee is sore. I must have {phrase}done something to{/phrase} it [=I must have hurt it] when I fell.
Don't just stand there: {phrase}do something{/phrase}! [=take some sort of action to stop what is happening]
We need to {phrase}do something about{/phrase} this problem. [=we need to take some action to correct this problem]
{phrase}All we can do{/phrase} is hope for the best. [=there is no other action we can take except to hope for the best]
I didn't {it}do{/it} it! = I didn't {phrase}do anything{/phrase}! [=I didn't do what you said I did]
Are you {phrase}doing anything{/phrase} right now? [=are you busy right now?]
If you're {phrase}not doing anything{/phrase} this evening [=if you're not busy this evening], why not come over for dinner?
{ldquo}What are you {it}doing{/it} this weekend?{rdquo} {ldquo}I'm just relaxing at home.{rdquo}
What is the stock market {it}doing{/it} now: rising or falling?
{phrase}What have I done with{/phrase} my keys? [=where did I put my keys?]
My hair is a mess. I {phrase}can't do anything with{/phrase} it.
There's {phrase}nothing to do{/phrase} in this town on a Saturday night!
{it}Do{/it} as I say, not as I {it}do{/it}. [=do the things that I say you should do, not the things that I do myself]
Shut up and {phrase}do as you're told{/phrase}! [=do what I tell you to do]

dt: used with {it}what{/it} to ask or talk about a person's job

dt.t: {ldquo}What does your husband {it}do{/it}?{rdquo} {ldquo}He's a writer.{rdquo}
She's a lawyer. I'm not sure what her husband {it}does{/it}.
What does she {phrase}do for a living{/phrase}? [=what is her job?]
His mother won't let him watch television until he has {it}done{/it} his homework.
I've only {it}done{/it} three of the walls so far—I'll paint the last one tomorrow.

dt: used to describe the success or progress of someone or something

dt.t: {ldquo}How is she {it}doing{/it} in school?{rdquo} {ldquo}She {it}did{/it} badly/poorly at first, but now she's {it}doing{/it} much better.{rdquo}
She {it}does{/it} well in math but badly in history.
The company is {it}doing{/it} well.
How is the stock market {it}doing{/it} these days?
He started out poor, worked hard, {it}did{/it} very well (for himself) in business [=was very successful in business], and died rich.

dt: {phrase}How are you doing?{/phrase} or (very informally) {phrase}How you doing?{/phrase} is used as a greeting.

dt.t: {ldquo}Hi, Dave. {it}How are you doing{/it}?{rdquo} {ldquo}I'm fine, thanks. How are you?{rdquo}

dt: used to describe the effect that something has

dt.t: You've been working too hard. A few days off will {phrase}do you (some) good{/phrase}. [=a few days off will be good for you]
We didn't mean to {phrase}do him (any) harm{/phrase}. [=to harm him]
Criticism can {it}do{/it} people a lot of harm/damage; praise can {it}do{/it} people a lot of good.
The new design {phrase}doesn't do much for{/phrase} me. [=I don't like the new design very much]
That hat {phrase}does nothing for you{/phrase}. [=that hat does not look good on you]

dt: used to describe the amount of effort someone makes

dt.t: She {it}did{/it} nothing to help us. [=she did not try to help us at all]
I {phrase}did my best{/phrase}. = I {phrase}did my utmost{/phrase}. = I {phrase}did all that I could{/phrase}. = I {phrase}did everything I could{/phrase}.
I {it}did{/it} as well as I could.
a writer who is {it}doing{/it} a new biography on Abraham Lincoln
a painter who has {it}done{/it} some beautiful landscapes

dt: {bc}to perform in or be the producer or director of (a movie, play, etc.)

dt.t: an actress who has {it}done{/it} several hit movies
a director who is {it}doing{/it} a play on Broadway
an actor who {it}did{/it} Hamlet on Broadway

dt: {bc}to pretend to be (someone, such as a famous person) {bc}to copy the speech and appearance of (someone)

dt.t: a comedian who {it}does{/it} a great George Bush [=a comedian who does a very good and entertaining imitation of George Bush]
I wish he'd {it}do{/it} a Houdini and disappear. [=I wish he'd go away]
It's your turn to {it}do{/it} [={it}wash{/it}] the laundry.
The woman we hired to clean our house doesn't {it}do{/it} windows.
They {it}did{/it} the bedroom in blue and the living room in green.

dt: {bc}to make (someone's face, hair, etc.) more attractive by putting on makeup, etc.

dt.t: She wanted to {it}do{/it} her face before the party.
She had her hair {it}done{/it} [={it}styled{/it}] at the beauty parlor.
She was {it}doing{/it} her fingernails/nails.
It took her a few minutes to {it}do{/it} her makeup.
I like my steak {it}done{/it} rare.
I'll {it}do{/it} the salad while you {it}do{/it} the pasta.
This is the company's most popular computer, but they also {it}do{/it} a less expensive model.

dt: {bc}to participate in (an activity) with other people

dt.t: We should {phrase}do dinner{/phrase} some time. [=we should have dinner together some time]
{it}do{/it} a meeting [=have a meeting]
We should {it}do{/it} a movie [=go to a movie] this weekend.
a group of tourists who are {it}doing{/it} [={it}visiting{/it}] 12 countries in 30 days
We {it}did{/it} [={it}traveled{/it}] 500 miles yesterday.
They were {it}doing{/it} [={it}going{/it}, {it}driving{/it}] 85 on the turnpike.
That plane can {it}do{/it} [={it}go{/it}] 1,400 mph!

dt: {bc}to be in a place for (a period of time)

dt.t: He {it}did{/it} [={it}spent{/it}] two years in college before he dropped out.

dt: {bc}to be in a prison for (a period of time)

dt.t: He {it}did{/it} [={it}served{/it}] five years (in prison) for robbery.
He has been {phrase}doing time{/phrase} in a federal penitentiary.
I've {phrase}done my time{/phrase} at that terrible job, and now it's time to move on.
I don't need any more cake, thank you. One piece {phrase}will do{/phrase}. [=one piece is enough]
I'd prefer to use glue, but tape {phrase}will/would do{/phrase}.
({it}informal{/it}) One piece of cake {it}will do{/it} me. [=one piece of cake is enough for me]

dt: Phrases like {phrase}that will do (it){/phrase} and {phrase}that should do (it){/phrase} are used in informal speech to tell someone that you do not want or need anything more.

dt.t: {ldquo}Would you like anything else?{rdquo} {ldquo}No, {it}that'll do it{/it}.{rdquo} = {ldquo}No, {it}that should do it{/it}.{rdquo}

dt: {it}That will do it{/it} and {it}that should do it{/it} are also used to say that you have finished doing something or are about to finish doing something.

dt.t: I just have one more letter to sign and {it}that should do it{/it}. [=and then I'll be finished]

dt: {it}That will do{/it} is also sometimes used to tell someone (such as a child) to stop doing or saying something that is bothering you or making you angry.

dt.t: {it}That will do{/it} [={it}that's enough{/it}], young man: one more word out of you and you're grounded!

dt: The phrase {phrase}that does it{/phrase} is used to say that you have finished doing something.

dt.t: I just need to sign one more letter…There, {it}that does it{/it}.

dt: {it}That does it{/it} is also used in angry speech to say that you will not accept or allow something anymore.

dt.t: {ldquo}They say we'll have to wait another hour.{rdquo} {ldquo}{it}That does it{/it}! We're leaving right now!{rdquo}

It {phrase}doesn't do{/phrase} for a doctor to become too friendly with his patients. = It {phrase}won't/wouldn't do{/phrase} for a doctor to become too friendly with his patients. [=a doctor should not become too friendly with his patients]
Such behavior will never {it}do{/it}! [=such behavior should not be allowed]
We should leave soon. It won't {it}do{/it} to be late.
This is a formal occasion, so jeans simply won't {it}do{/it}. [=jeans are not appropriate]

dt: In U.S. English, this sense of {it}do{/it} has a somewhat formal or old-fashioned quality.

dt.t: He says that he doesn't {it}do{/it} drugs anymore.
Is there anything {it}doing{/it} tomorrow?
There is nothing {it}doing{/it} around here.
Let's find out {phrase}what's doing{/phrase} downtown.

dt: People ask {phrase}what is something/someone doing…?{/phrase} when they are surprised or upset about where someone or something is.

dt.t: {it}What are all my clothes doing{/it} (lying/scattered) on the floor? [=why are all my clothes on the floor?]
{it}What were you doing{/it} (standing) outside in the rain? [=why were you outside in the rain?]

dt: People ask {phrase}what is someone doing with (something)?{/phrase} when they are surprised or upset because someone has something.

dt.t: {it}What are you doing with{/it} my notebook? = {phrase}What do you think you're doing with{/phrase} my notebook? [=why do you have my notebook?]
She's accused of hiring a hit man to {it}do away with{/it} [={it}murder, do in{/it}] her husband.

dt: {bc}to cause the end of (something) {bc}to get rid of (something)

dt.t: The struggling company had to {it}do away with{/it} a number of jobs.

dt: {bc}to deal with or treat (someone) well or badly

dt.t: She feels that they {it}did{/it} poorly/badly {it}by{/it} her. [=that they treated her poorly/badly]
They {phrase}did pretty well by{/phrase} me when I retired. [=they treated me pretty well when I retired]

dt: {bc}to talk about (someone) in an insulting or critical way

dt.t: She thinks that if she {it}does{/it} everybody else {it}down{/it}, people will think more highly of her.
Stop {it}doing{/it} yourself {it}down{/it}: you've got a lot to offer!

dt: {bc}to cause the death or ruin of (someone)

dt.t: All that hard work nearly {it}did for{/it} him. [=nearly killed him]

dt: {bc}to do the cleaning and cooking for (someone)

dt.t: Mrs. Jones {it}does for{/it} the vicar now his wife's passed on.
They threatened to {it}do{/it} him {it}in{/it} if he didn't pay the money he owed them.
He's been so depressed lately that his friends are afraid he might {phrase}do himself in{/phrase}. [=he might kill himself]
He struggled with lung disease for many years, but it was a heart attack that finally {it}did{/it} him {it}in{/it}.
His inability to attract Southern voters is what finally {it}did{/it} him {it}in{/it} as a presidential candidate. [=he failed because he was unable to attract Southern voters]
a businessman who was {it}done in{/it} by greed
Working in the garden all day really {it}did{/it} me {it}in{/it}. = After working in the garden all day, I was/felt {it}done in{/it}. [={it}exhausted{/it}]
They've kissed—but have they actually {it}done it{/it}?

dt: {bc}to unfairly prevent (someone) from getting or having (something)

dt.t: I've been {it}done out of{/it} what was rightfully mine!
They {it}did{/it} [={it}cheated{/it}] him {it}out of{/it} his inheritance.
I made a mistake when I measured the window and I had to {it}do{/it} it {it}over{/it} (again).
If I had to {it}do{/it} it (all) {it}over{/it} again, I would have stayed in college.

dt: {bc}to decorate or change a room, house, etc., so that it looks very different

dt.t: We're planning to {it}do over{/it} the kitchen next year.
He got {it}done over{/it} by a gang of teenagers.
They {it}did up{/it} the room in bright colors for the party. = The room was all {it}done up{/it} in bright colors for the party.

dt: {bc}to adjust (something, such as your hair) in a particular way

dt.t: She {it}did up{/it} her hair in a ponytail.
packages {it}done up{/it} [={it}wrapped up{/it}] in paper and ribbon
{it}do up{/it} [={it}fix up{/it}] old furniture
{it}do up{/it} an old house

dt: {bc}to dress (someone) up {bc}to put attractive clothes, makeup, etc., on (someone)

dt.t: She really {phrase}did herself up{/phrase} for the party. = She was all {it}done up{/it} for the party.

dt: {bc}to be fastened or to fasten (something) with buttons, a zipper, etc.

dt.t: a dress that {it}does up{/it} at the back = a dress that is {it}done up{/it} at the back
She {it}did up{/it} her dress.
buttons that {it}do up{/it} easily = buttons that you can {it}do up{/it} easily [=buttons that can be easily buttoned]

dt: If you {phrase}would do well{/phrase} to do something, you should do it.

dt.t: You {it}would do well{/it} to avoid him right now. [=you should avoid him right now]

dt: If you {phrase}did well{/phrase} to do something, you were correct to do it.

dt.t: You {it}did well to avoid{/it} him when he was in a bad mood.

dt: If you {phrase}did well to escape, survive{/phrase}, etc., you were lucky to escape, survive, etc.

dt.t: When the tornado hit, they {it}did well to escape{/it} uninjured.
I {phrase}could (really) do with{/phrase} a cup of hot coffee right now! [=I could use a cup of coffee; I would like/appreciate a cup of coffee]
I {it}could do with{/it} a little less criticism right now, if you don't mind!

dt: {bc}to not have (something) {bc}to live, work, etc., without having (something)

dt.t: If you can't afford a new car, you'll just have to {it}do without{/it} (one).
I don't know how we ever {it}did without{/it} computers.
I'd like to get a new car, but I can {it}do without{/it} it for now.

dt: The phrase {phrase}can/could do without{/phrase} is often used to say that you do not like or approve of something.

dt.t: I enjoy traveling, but I {it}can do without{/it} having to wait around in crowded airports. [=I don't like having to wait around]
He was late again. That's the kind of selfish behavior I {it}could do without{/it}.
The problem {it}has to do with{/it} fishing rights. = ({it}chiefly Brit{/it}) The problem {it}is to do with{/it} fishing rights.

{ldquo}What does her husband do?{rdquo} {ldquo}I think {phrase}it has something to do with{/phrase} computers.{rdquo} = {ldquo}I think {phrase}it's got something to do with{/phrase} computers.{rdquo} [=it involves computers in some way]
That's your problem: {phrase}it has nothing to do with{/phrase} me! = ({it}chiefly Brit{/it}) {it}It's nothing to do with{/it} me! [=it doesn't involve me in any way; it's not my problem]
You're wrong. {phrase}It's got everything to do with{/phrase} you: you're legally responsible for what went wrong.

dt: {bc}to be involved in or in some way responsible for (something)

dt.t: He claims that he {phrase}had nothing to do with{/phrase} the accident. = He claims that he {phrase}didn't have anything to do with{/phrase} the accident. [=that he was not involved in the accident]
He claims he wasn't involved, but I know he {phrase}had something to do with{/phrase} it.

dt: If you do not want to {phrase}have anything to do with{/phrase} someone or if you {phrase}want nothing to do with{/phrase} someone, you do not want to be involved with that person in any way.

dt.t: She thinks he's a liar and she refuses to {it}have anything to do with{/it} him. [=she refuses to talk to him, to see him, etc.]
After the way he's treated me, I {it}want nothing (further) to do{/it} with him. = I {it}don't want (to have) anything (further) to do{/it} with him.

shortdef: —used with what to ask or talk about a person's job
